author: thiago.ouros
title: Google Search Blockfrost
description: Blockfrost needs to be better known among devs, as does Ethereum's Infura, for example. One of the ways to achieve this goal is the production of SEO-oriented educational content.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal does an excellent job answering the call of the challenge. While Blockfrost already have a well documented api with a sleuth of sdks more than enough for most dev already in the ecosystem, writing tutorial style "seo-optimized content" is an excellent way to help new devs discover Cardano and Blockfrost. 

Key metrics like proposal education target aligns well with the challenge. The proposal is aware of multiple risks and has well-thought out solutions to mitigate them.
f6_assessments.q1: Deliverables and milestone over a three months period are well detailed in the proposal. Budget is reasonable with clear details and line items. The team has both the writing and technical experience to pull this off with linked profiles of both members provided.
f6_assessments.q2: Deliverables and KPI are straight forward with the project. The proposal has promise monthly deliverables in the form of articles, and tutorial code on github. This is something the community can see, track and audit. Would have love to see some detail on how the team plan to organize and track progress or roadblocks on the work and how the community might optionally be able track and audit that.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal effectively addresses 3 of the 4 guiding questions mentioned in the challenge brief making it highly impactful. The suggestion to create search engine optimized content is not terribly original, but if executed well, has the potential to drive the outcomes suggested in the proposal. The idea to piggyback on popular search queries for related but different products (eg Infura) is quite interesting. As someone that has done web dev and search engine marketing in the past, this indicates to me that the proposers have a strong understanding of the craft, and have likely already done keyword research to justify their approach.
f6_assessments.q1: The team appears well equipped to execute this proposal given related experience in technical writing and entrepreneurship. The 3 month proposal seems to be paced reasonably. Given my own background in producing SEO content, I support the plan to begin with thorough keyword research and clear description of the target audience. These are key foundations for proper execution.
f6_assessments.q2: The team provides clear milestones and KPIs they intend to track. As someone with experience managing delivery of projects and measuring ROI, I would've liked to see specific targets on what the team hopes to accomplish (going beyond just listing measurements). While I appreciate the definition of success described, it relies on being able to measure metrics that may not be available outside the Blockfrost team, making it potentially difficult to measure against that success criteria.

f6_assessments.q0: This is a great idea and a well-structured proposal. The team has identified the problem of lack of visibility of Blackfrost by developers in general and has proposed an effective solution to it. They have articulated in a clear manner how their proposal will add value to the Cardano ecosystem; by disseminating the different uses and qualities of Blockfrost through articles and tutorials they will end up attracting new developers and developers from the crypto space that have not joined the Cardano environment yet. The metrics they are using, number of accesses to their content, number of articles produced per month and number of forks and downloads on GitHub align to the challenge as they translate a successful implementation.
f6_assessments.q1: The team has provided enough evidence of their experience. Links to their LinkedIn profiles were given in the proposal together with descriptions of past experiences and their history with Cardano. They have also been previously funded in former campaigns which is valuable experience. The number of required members to implement the idea is basically the two proposers and they have the skills needed to do it (digital marketing, Cardano-related experience and translation). The budget requested is reasonable, it is clear what the funds will be used for and it aligns with the goals they have set. Mainly the resources will be directed to research, strategy and content creation. The time horizons they have defined are realistic, in total it will take three months to complete the project and each month there are objectively measurable deliverables. Finally, the three main risks they have raised are relevant and the proposed mitigating solutions effective. Technical questions could delay the production of the articles, the performance of SEO could not reach what they were expecting and the blog might not be able to be implemented. Their solutions may result in additional spending or depending on the assistance of Blockfrost but they are valid workarounds.
f6_assessments.q2: The roadmap traced has clear milestones and achievable time horizons. The project has been divided into three phases each one with deliverables. Each phase lasts one month and at the end of month one, for example, there will be 2 articles produced, a persona characterized, and the platforms for which the content will be created delineated. The team has specified precise metrics, number of accesses to published content, articles produced, and number of forks, downloads and stars on GitHub. These are all objective, easy-to-measure KPIs that clearly indicate if the proposal has been successful or not. Additionally, the targeted problem, Blockfrost's lack of visibility, was precisely described throughout the proposal which shows a thorough understanding of the problem. The only point the proposal missed was providing, in a clear manner, a public channel to post regular updates on the progress of the plan. That would enhance the auditability of the project and in turn the credibility of the proposal.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal addresses the challenge in 2 ways. The first is  creating  a library of search terms to use in articles about Blockfrost. The second is creating educational media about Blockfrost.

The proposal only shows one example of search terms, based on that, creating a library of search terms is a small task, and will not do much to increase adoption.

The Campaign brief does mention blog, posts, articles and tutorials. The proposal does not have any detail about the strategy, direction, or content of the media. For this reason it is difficult to evaluate the effectiveness. 

The proposal addresses some minor parts of the challenge, but does not address the whole challenge.
f6_assessments.q1:
It looks like a good team for this kind of project. One member is very experienced with Cardano, and clearly very passionate about it. The other partner is an experienced writer of web content and is well suited to create the library of search terms.


The plan has realistic goals around content creation, The can manage four educational pieces per month, and they propose fair compensation for that.
f6_assessments.q2:
The criteria for assessment are clear and objective. The measurements are basically clicks and downloads of educational materials. These do not measure adoption. There is a missing piece here of how do we track if someone actually starts to use Cardano and Blockfrost?

There are things to measure, but they will not tell us much about the success of addressing the challenge.

f6_assessments.q0:
This is one of the best ideas to make aware of blockfrost to developers around the world, where people around the globe use google to search for the required data, and setting up seeds based on search is definitely good idea to bring interest in people.
When more times the blockfrost data is seen the browser tends to open it and tries to understand the data, this will not only enhance his developing skill to use blockfrost it will also enhance him in understand the projects of blockfrost. hence, this proposal effectively addresses the challenge
f6_assessments.q1:
As Nunes has worked as digital marketing agency for more than 7 years , he has clear idea what are the main seed words that people will use to understand any new data from the google. Since these seed words development has enhanced by Ethereum search already, making a copy of it wont be much difficult, the only challenging task here is finding the right key words which all are related to the blockfrost development kit.
The team has already experienced people in creating contents the lan presented it is highly likely this proposal will be implemented successfully.
f6_assessments.q2:
The described solution for the proposal is presented clearly where proposer has presented idea of "addresses 3 points of the guiding questions" , the proposer has even presented what are the risk that would be involved in his project in cleared manner.
The presented plan has decent timeline and budget breaking of the project , the proposer has provided details of the team with whom he'll be working and their expertise field so with the decent data presented. the information provided is sufficient to audit the progress and the success of the proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: The goal of this proposal is to literally bring more developers to Blockfrost through SEO. Thus, if the proposal is successful, then the goals of the challenge are met. Many people perform websearches for content related to development. This is something I do regularly. I can see how people searching for Cardano’s Infura would be able to identify Blockfrost if it showed up on a regular basis. If this proposal is approved and implemented successfully, many new people would learn about Blockfrost and start using it to develop on Cardano.
f6_assessments.q1: This proposal has a clear plan for growing organic search results for Blockfrost, but I am not certain how successful they will be. The proess of growing SEO through content creation is not a one to one activity. There are elements of this process that the team cannot control. The goal is admirable, however, and the process of creating good content that people consume does indeed have a strong correlation to increased SEO. But, in this case, the content numbers also seem a little low. Their goal is only a total of ten articles over the next three months. That seems a bit too few to really drive SEO numbers up by much. And the budget is a little less detailed than would be ideal to prove feasibility. The proposal is not ideal in presenting its feasibility, but it does have a sufficient basis for success. I am giving it a three for this reason.
f6_assessments.q2: If approved, this proposal would be sufficiently auditable. They will plan on releasing ten articles over the next three months. These articles should be searchable and will be available to verify completion. The general KPIs would hopefully be available in  the monthly reports this team will submit to Catalyst. Other than that, they do not really list any other auditable  metrics. The proposal is clear, but it is not as detailed as it might need to be to receive full acceptance by the broader community. That is why I rated it a 4.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal aims to increase awareness of Blockfrost by creating SEO-optimized content and educational materials in the form of blog posts, articles, and tutorials.

This campaign aims to: "Different open-source initiatives building an active ecosystem around Blockfrost, from tooling to frameworks." This proposal does not fit the objectives but may help to attract new developers to use blockfrost.
f6_assessments.q1:
The team members are experienced in writing technology articles. In addition, one of the team members has technical experience in Cardano. There are links to their linkedin profiles where it is possible to check their experience and skills.

They present a monthly action plan. Each article has a technical and SEO research behind it. After 3 months they will have written 10 articles. The total budget is 12000$ which corresponds to a salary of 2000$ per month over the 3 months of work for the 2 members of the team.
f6_assessments.q2:
The metrics to follow the development of the project are based on the publication of the articles at the end of each month. It would be beneficial to use a public document management platform in the cloud to see the drafts of the articles before publishing the final version. This allows to track the evolution of the project in a more transparent way.

The ways to measure the success of the project are correct but this is difficult to measure: "Number of forks, downloads or stars on GitHub" since not all of this data will be related to the articles.

solution: Producing SEO-optimized content with keywords searched by devs creates opportunities to introduce them to Blockfrost and to invite them to get onboard.
experience:
